title: Neural Effects of Exercise, Cognitive, or Combined Training in AD At-Risk Elders
description_brief: The purpose of this study is to gain a better understanding of the effects of exercise and cognitive training on improving brain function in healthy older adults who may be at risk for developing Alzheimer's Disease.
explanation_target: Reason: The trial tests exercise and cognitive training (and their combination) in healthy older adults at risk for Alzheimer's disease to improve brain function. These are non-pharmacologic, behavioral interventions intended to improve cognition / brain health rather than a biologic or small-molecule therapy that targets AD pathology (e.g., amyloid or tau).

Act: Key details extracted from the description — intervention: exercise and cognitive training (separately and combined); population: healthy older adults at risk for AD; intended effect: improve brain function / cognition. This does not involve a drug, monoclonal antibody, vaccine, or small-molecule agent, so it cannot be classified as a disease-targeted biologic or disease-targeted small molecule. The "cognitive enhancer" category was defined for drugs that improve cognition without targeting pathology, so a behavioral/non-drug cognitive intervention also does not meet that category per the provided definitions. Therefore the correct classification is 'N/A'.

Reflect: The classification was checked against the provided category definitions: - Disease-targeted biologic: requires a biologic (monoclonal antibody, vaccine) — not present. - Disease-targeted small molecule: requires a small-molecule drug — not present. - Cognitive enhancer: defined as drugs — intervention here is non-pharmacologic. - Neuropsychiatric symptom improvement: targets behavioral/psychiatric symptoms (e.g., agitation, depression) — not the focus. Given these definitions, 'N/A' is appropriate. No ambiguity about a drug exists in the trial description.

Web search results supporting that exercise and combined exercise+cognitive training are non-pharmacologic interventions studied to improve cognition/brain health in at-risk older adults (selected sources): 1) SYNERGIC randomized trial: aerobic-resistance exercise plus computerized cognitive training improved cognition in older adults with MCI (demonstrates exercise + cognitive training used to improve cognition). citeturn1search4 2) Train the Brain randomized trial: combined physical/cognitive training in aged MCI subjects showed cognitive and brain changes after combined training. citeturn1search8 3) Systematic review: combined cognitive and exercise interventions can improve cognition in older adults with and without impairment. citeturn1search2 4) Longitudinal study: higher physical activity linked to reduced hippocampal atrophy in elders at genetic risk for AD (supports role of exercise in brain preservation). citeturn1search7 5) EEG study: combined cognitive and physical training produced neuroplastic changes indexed by EEG in at-risk older adults. citeturn1search0
